title: How to Take a Before Shot

steps.headline: Decide if it's a good scenario for before/after shots.
steps.description:
Times when you might want a "before" shot include:
An area before a major cleanup; like an oil spill, construction, destruction, etc. When going on an improved, or at least different, health regimen, whether it is to gain, or lose, weight. Renovating a house
Cleaning a house (sometimes, people just don't believe it was really that dirty!) For litigation...you just never know.

steps.headline: Step back and look at the upcoming project.
steps.description: You might need to clean it up a bit if it is a construction project or not, if it is a cleanup project.

steps.headline: Take both close shots and wide shots.
Be sure to take shots from various angles.
steps.description: You will regret it if you don't. You will need them for reference later.

steps.headline: Double check the shots.
steps.description: Look at them and make sure that they will serve the purpose and are in focus.

steps.headline: Print up the pictures.
steps.description: If it is a long term project then you might want to have a 'before' shot hanging around so you can see your progress.

steps.headline: Take 'during' and 'after' shots.
steps.description: Try to take these shots at the same, or similar, angles.

steps.headline: Wear clothing that isn't too loose or too tight.
Be sure that the clothing can be seen.
steps.description: If you are dark skinned, don't wear black clothing. You will want to be able to see the trouble spots. This is one time you don't want to hide them!

steps.headline: Make sure your area is as uncluttered as possible.
Shoot from all angles.
steps.description: Again, you want the reference for later. Front, side, and back for weight loss shots.

steps.headline: Walk around the area.
steps.description: Get a feel for what you want to photograph.

steps.headline: Get down on the ground and be prepared to climb to get as many perspectives as you can get.
Use a wide angle for at least some of the shots.
steps.description: You want to be able to get as much of the entire project in one shot.

steps.headline: Take more than you think you will ever need.
steps.description: That way you will have your choice of photographs.

steps.headline: Use a wide angle lens to get a few shots of the entire (or most of it anyway) room.
Be sure that you get as close as you can to as many areas as you can.
steps.description: If there are particular issues, be sure to get shots of them.

steps.headline: Take some that aren't quite as close.
steps.description: It's a good idea to make sure that you can tell that your close shot is part of another photograph. Be able to relate them.

text:
Steps Decide if it's a good scenario for before/after shots. Times when you might want a "before" shot include:
An area before a major cleanup; like an oil spill, construction, destruction, etc. When going on an improved, or at least different, health regimen, whether it is to gain, or lose, weight. Renovating a house
Cleaning a house (sometimes, people just don't believe it was really that dirty!) For litigation...you just never know. Step back and look at the upcoming project. You might need to clean it up a bit if it is a construction project or not, if it is a cleanup project. Take both close shots and wide shots.  Be sure to take shots from various angles. You will regret it if you don't. You will need them for reference later. Double check the shots. Look at them and make sure that they will serve the purpose and are in focus. Print up the pictures. If it is a long term project then you might want to have a 'before' shot hanging around so you can see your progress. Take 'during' and 'after' shots. Try to take these shots at the same, or similar, angles. Weight Loss Wear clothing that isn't too loose or too tight.  Be sure that the clothing can be seen. If you are dark skinned, don't wear black clothing. You will want to be able to see the trouble spots. This is one time you don't want to hide them! Make sure your area is as uncluttered as possible.  Shoot from all angles. Again, you want the reference for later. Front, side, and back for weight loss shots. Landscaping Walk around the area. Get a feel for what you want to photograph. Get down on the ground and be prepared to climb to get as many perspectives as you can get.  Use a wide angle for at least some of the shots. You want to be able to get as much of the entire project in one shot. Take more than you think you will ever need. That way you will have your choice of photographs. Home Design Use a wide angle lens to get a few shots of the entire (or most of it anyway) room.  Be sure that you get as close as you can to as many areas as you can. If there are particular issues, be sure to get shots of them. Take some that aren't quite as close. It's a good idea to make sure that you can tell that your close shot is part of another photograph. Be able to relate them.
